title: Ten Commandments of the Small Internet
description: A grassroots Internet movement called
notes: A grassroots Internet movement called \"the small Internet\" is afoot. Here are ten commandments that Cheapskates would like to see largely obeyed on the small Internet.

title: What I Learned about the Internet by Creating My Own Website
description: Here are some things I learned about the Internet by creating my own website.
notes: Here are some things Cheapskates learned about the Internet by creating their own website.

title: Nostalgia Is Bullshit __________ _ _ _ _ RACE THE NiGHT
notes: September shares with us their thoughts about web 1.0 design nostalgia. Like all nostalgia, it's bullshit.

title: The Return of the 90s Web
author: Max Böck
description: Are we ready to revisit some of the ideas of the early web again? There are trends that suggest we might just have come full circle - and I like it.
notes: Max wonders if having your own website is trendy again.

title: Seven Reasons for having a Personal Website
description: There are at least seven reasons you should have a personal website.
notes: There are at least seven reasons you should have a personal website. Cheapskates lets us know what they are.

title: The Missing Hit and the Open Web
author: Jim Nielsen
description: Writing about the big beautiful mess that is making things for the world wide web.
notes: If it doesn't appear in google's search results, does it really exist?

title: Making the Web Fun Again
description: Ever since I visited my first web site (via a slow modem to a library BBS running a text-based web browser), I have been ceaselessly pondering the nature of ...
notes: Kyle looks at how the web could be made fun again.

title: Underscores, Optimization & Arms Races - Anil Dash
author: undefined
description: A blog about making culture. Since 1999.
notes: A dozen years ago, the web started to reshape itself around major companies like Google. We can understand the genesis of today’s algorithmic arms race against the tech titans just by looking at a single character...

title: The modern web is becoming an unusable, user-hostile wasteland
description: Some thoughts about the modern web
notes: The question is: at which point do we reach the breaking point?

title: I Miss the Old Internet
author: Tie
description: I miss the internet of the early 1990's.
notes: The author, Tie, misses the Internet of the early 1990's.

title: manifesto
author: sadgrl
description: The old web refers to the internet's former iteration. It includes Web 1.0 and the early parts of Web 2.0. It is known as the age of chat rooms, message boards, Myspace and Livejournal.
notes: The page that started a... something... We, the people of the Internet, have the power to restore it to its former glory.

title: Autonomy Online: A Case For The IndieWeb — Smashing Magazine
description: There is an alternative to corporate bubbles online — it’s called the IndieWeb. Build your own personal websites, control your online presence, and learn on your own terms.
notes: There is an alternative to corporate bubbles online — it’s called the indieweb. build your own personal websites, control your online presence, and learn on your own terms.

title: Hunting the Nearly-Invisible Personal Website
description: Personal websites have become nearly invisible on the Internet. This article suggests a few techniques for finding them.
notes: Cheapskates goes hunting. The personal website is a somewhat mysterious animal that lives mostly unobserved in the jungle of the Internet

title: I Got The Internet Going Nutz: Kreayshawn and 10 Years of SOMETHIN' BOUT KREAY' - MGRM
author: Jacqueline Codiga
description: Ten years after the release of Kreayshawn's SOMETHIN' BOUT KREAY', there are plenty of lessons to be learned about the era and the music.
notes: This article reflects on the 10th anniversary of rapper Kreayshawn's debut album Somethin Bout Kreay and how it marked a significant moment in internet culture. Kreayshawn really had it hard. She blew up on the Internet before there was a means to monitise it. It dives into the troubles she faced with the virality and her eventual departure from the spotlight.

title: 2023, the year of websites
author: Andy Bell
description: 2023 is going to be the year of websites—specifically personal websites—and I'm here for it. It seems like the momentum for people to hyper-focus (or re-focus) on their personal home on the World W…
notes: 2023 will be the year of websites as people become more aware of the value of owning their content and digital identity. Andy, like myself, encourages everyone to start building their own websites to have more control over their online presence and the ability to showcase their work. Check out the article for tips and resources for building your own website.

title: Build your metadata library
author: Katy DeCorah
description: Last year, I started to track new recipes I tried and books I read by saving their metadata to YAML files. I had already been saving Spotify playlists in the...
notes: This has kept me busy for the past 6 weeks. Katy explains the importance of metadata in web development and provides a step-by-step guide on creating and managing metadata using Github actions. She also emphasizes the need for developers to prioritize metadata in their workflow and explains how it can help improve search engine optimization and accessibility of websites. One thing that I have found while implementing my own metadata library is that metadata could be a lot better. I've had to do a lot of manual editing to get things looking nice.

title: Organizing the Eleventy config file
author: Lene Saile
description: Eleventy lets you create a file called eleventy.js to configure the SSG to your own project's needs. This article is all about organizing your config file!
notes: Lene dives deep and discusses how you could approach organising your Eleventy config file.

title: Firefox found a way to keep ad-blockers working with Manifest V3
author: Mitchell Clark
description: It plays nice with uBlock Origin.

title: Is Amos Burton a Sociopath?
author: Lane Zumoff
description: If you're reading this you're probably a fan of Amazon Prime's hit series The Expanse. If not, and you're simply wondering who Amos Burton is and why people are calling him names
notes: At first glance yup, but this article dives deeper to discover that Amos is indeed a complex person.

title: Sonos / Spotify Vinyl Emulator
description: Experience the tactile nature of a vinyl music collection (but without actually owning any vinyl) through Sonos, Spotify and NFC tags By Mark Hank.
note: Have you ever wanted to build a vinyl emulator? This post will guide you through doing exactly that with a Raspberry Pi, a USB turn table and a Sonos sound system. Play vinyl records on the Sonos system and control the turntable remotely through the web.

title: How to fix the internet
author: Paul J Miller
notes: Written in 2015. Should the tech giants control user-created content like videos, podcasts, music and blogs? Think of a web where standard and open formats such as .video, .podcast, .blog, and .tweet exist. They are not tied to apps rented to you by the tech giants. An entire ecosystem exists for users to choose how to consume this open and free content. I love these ideas and would love to work on something to push this...

title: Maybe the web should die
author: Paul J Miller
notes: Written in 2015, this seems even more relevant today in 2023. The Web shouldn't die, but content that exists solely to sell ads should. The current state of the Web is problematic due to issues like surveillance capitalism, monopolies, and social media's negative impact. Show the Web in its current form die so that something better can emerge in its place? This article is another call for people to take ownership of their data and participate in building a better web.

title: The Year of the Personal Website
author: Matthias Ott
description: Matthias Ott is an independent user experience designer and developer from Stuttgart, Germany. Besides design practice he teaches Interface Prototyping at the Muthesius Academy of Fine Arts and Design, Kiel.
notes: Have you heard me say 'create your own homepage!' before? Make 2023 the year we take back the web!

title: Own your stuff
author: Bryce Wray
description: Because the only constant is change, you shouldn't depend on others to keep your content online.
notes: Another article stresses the importance of owning and controlling your digital content rather than relying on social media or other platforms. Owning your content gives control over its distribution and longevity and reduces the risk of losing it due to how the tech giants feel about a particular service. Bryce offers practical tips and tools to create and host your own website or blog.

title: Blasts from the past
author: Bryce Wray
description: To save you the trouble, I revisit previous posts in search of useful info.
notes: Is the Internet broken, or has the way use it created the issues we see today? We could all take accountability for how we engage with content on the Internet and each other to avoid things such as sharing misleading or false information and work to make the Internet a better place for everyone.

title: There Can Be Money in Blogging - Chris Coyier
author: Chris Coyier
description: When you hear me endlessly prattle on about how you should have your own site, publish your own feed, and the general power of writing, I mean it. But why? What's the point of writing on your own site? So many. Not to mention it's fun! But there can be money in blogging too: You […]
notes: I don't care for the making money parts, but the other points are solid.

title: The internet is not broken. People are. - Manu
author: Manu
description: That magical place that is Hacker News managed to fish up this piece of content today, from the depths of the web. And I am very grateful for that. …

title: Welcome to the new Verge
author: Nilay Patel
description: A complete redesign of The Verge that marries the best of old-school blogging with a modern news feed experience.
notes: I'm interested to see how this works out for The Verge. Their redesign aims to provide a better user experience by improving the navigation, reducing clutter, and emphasizing the content. I've enjoyed reading so far and paying attention to who the authors of the blog posts are.

title: Bring back personal blogging
author: Monique Judge
description: The personal blog built the internet, and maybe it can fix it.
notes: I whole heartedly agree with the message in this post, I share similar thoughts in my manifesto.

title: In Defense of a Fussy Website
author: Sarah Drasner
description: The other day I was doom-scrolling twitter, and I saw a delightful article titled “The Case for Fussy Breakfasts.” I love food and especially breakfast, and
notes: It is evident when a website has been crafted with care and excitement. It can enhance user experience and improve the overall perception of a brand. I love discovering new websites where the webmaster has done just that. It's great to stand out from the crowd and helps me identify whether a real person is behind the website.

title: Just Put Stuff Out There
author: Matthias Ott
description: Matthias Ott is an independent user experience designer and developer from Stuttgart, Germany. Besides design practice he teaches Interface Prototyping at the Muthesius Academy of Fine Arts and Design, Kiel.
notes: We all fall trap to this. Create and share your work with the world instead of holding back and waiting for perfection. Putting oneself out there and learning from mistakes is essential to the creative process. Learning in public is one of the fun things about the Web.

title: A Web that Reflects People and their Val… — Jacky Alciné
author: Jacky Alciné
notes: Dive into the current state of the internet and the rise of decentralised projects attempting to offer an alternative to the tech giants. Jacky expresses their desire for an alternative social networking system that allows them to publish and share content while maintaining control over their data. I like emphasising this exact message in every conversation about posting your content online.

title: Why is your site like this?
author: Di
notes: Fellow small web enthusiast Di explores why they write, including the desire to create something beautiful and meaningful, the need to process their thoughts and emotions, and the hope to connect with others through their writing. Writing is an act of self-discovery and a way to make sense of the world around them.

title: Smashmouth's White Magic
author: Zach Mandeville
description: Older esoteric standup piece
notes: Zach dives into Smashmouth's hidden, mystical significance, particularly the references to hermetic alchemy in their music. It hilariously ends with a warning of the dangers of bands like Third Eye Blind, who use the occult arts to obfuscate and block spiritual clarity.

title: A Web Renaissance
author: Anil Dash
description: A blog about making culture. Since 1999.
notes: Written in 2022, Anil declares the internet is experiencing a new wave of innovation and creativity, similar to the early days of the web. Dash cites the proliferation of web-based apps, the rise of decentralized technologies like blockchain, and the increasing focus on privacy and security as signs of this renaissance. He also emphasizes the importance of building a web that is open and accessible to all rather than controlled by a few tech giants. Dash advocates for a renewed focus on the core values of the web, including decentralization, interoperability, and community-driven innovation.

title: The future of blogging
author: Koos Looijesteijn
description: Good things are coming to the web!
notes: Koos discusses the challenges and opportunities for bloggers in a rapidly evolving online landscape, emphasizing the importance of adapting to changing trends and technologies and creating high-quality content that provides value to readers. He also explores the potential for emerging technologies, such as artificial intelligence and virtual reality, to shape the future of blogging. I can get behind this.

title: Miley's Whole Career Has Been Building to This Moment
author: Rob Sheffield
description: Miley Cyrus' smash hit “Flowers”— and 'Endless Summer Vacation,' due Friday — are the culmination of one of pop's longest, most bizarre stories
notes: I'm so happy that Miley is finally getting her flowers. How has Miley evolved as an artist over the years? How has she succeeded despite her personal struggles? Will Endless Summer Vacation be a hit?

title: No, Blogging Is Not Dying Anytime Soon  - Darius Foroux
author: Darius Foroux
description: A well-known author said, “Blogging is dead. People only watch videos.” Sure, visual content is popular. But there are still people who read.
notes: The author argues against video content creators' claim that blogging is dead. Video is not my favourite way to consume information. I still enjoy a well-written article. The key takeaway is to spend your time doing the thing you like.

title: I don't want to log in to your website
author: Elizabeth Lopatto
description: Just say no to salesbros!
notes: This article examines how relying on tech giants for user authentication and advertising has complicated the web. Web developers should prioritise user privacy and find ways to reduce reliance on tech giants. I avoid participating with websites that push "login with x" prompts on me. I shouldn't have to log in to anything to read a simple page of text.

title: Dot-com – Vague, But Exciting
notes: This article briefly analyses the dot-com boom and bust between 1995 and 2001. It also looks into the rise of Amazon and how Bezos made it a success amidst the dot-com bust.

title: The Story Of How ODB Recorded His Verse For Mariah Carey’s Remix Is Fantastic
description: In 1995 Mariah Carey scored her ninth #1 single with "Fantasy." From her fifth album, Daydream, the song offered a nod to Grandmaster Flash and The Furious Five, by sampling…
notes: I've been enjoying season 3 of Wu-Tang: An American Saga and was reminded of this article while watching episode 7, Shadowboxin. This article recounts the hilarious way ODB's verse came to be on the Fantasy remix by Mariah Carey.

title: The Fight for the Open Web
description: Now that "the fight for the open web" is here, we must ask ourselves: how did Web3 come to dominate the conversation over previous initiatives? And what should we do about it?
notes: There’s no better time than now to fight for the freedom of the web. While web3 might not be the answer, it has brought the topic of web freedom to the forefront of discussion. Ultimately, the best way to fight for the web is to build. Build and participate in an open and free web!

title: Discover personal websites
author: sizeof(cat)
description: The year is 2023 and when you want to discover new personal websites on your favorite search engine, you just get bombarded with an endless stream of junk. If those are the alternatives, how do you reach out to those unique, fringy, weird and interesting websites? Well, I think I might have something to help you in your research.
notes: Another (hilarious) article emphasises the importance of website discovery. I'm nodding while reading, agreeing with the absolute state of search results. Provides some tips and resources for discovering new websites. Always be on the lookout for personal recommendations to find new exciting websites.

title: We Should Replace Facebook With Personal Websites
description: Personal websites and email can replace most of what people like about Facebook—namely the urge to post about their lives online.
notes: Personal websites and email can replace most of what people like about Facebook—namely the urge to post about their lives online. Why did we abandon personal websites in favour of the social network platform of the month?

title: The Story Behind Lil Kim’s Iconic Louis Vuitton Logo-Print Portrait
description: David LaChapelle tells us the whole history of how the image came together. Plus: a casino-themed Kardashian family Christmas card.
notes: The Story Behind Lil Kim’s Iconic Louis Vuitton Logo-Print Portrait

title: “I Realise Now How Harshly I Was Judged”: Miley Cyrus On Finding Her Peace – And Making The Album Of The Summer
author: Condé Nast
description: “I’ve been in the Garden of Eden before and I’ve taken the red apple, and it never feels good,” Cyrus tells British Vogue in an in-depth interview.
notes: Miley Cyrus' latest interview with British Vogue. Delve into this fascinating article to gain insights into the multi-talented artist's life, thoughts, and creative journey. How does she embrace authenticity and challenge societal norms? She shares her unique perspective on fashion, music, and personal growth.

title: For Katie Holmes, It’s Always Been About the Work
author: Condé Nast
description: She's got stellar personal style, an admirable ability to parent privately, and a seemingly permanent spot on the paparazzi's must-capture list. But behind it all, Katie Holmes is—and always has been—a passionate and successful actor and director.

title: Web rings: An alternative to search engines | Casey | College & Research Libraries News
description: Web rings: An alternative to search engines
notes: Looking to explore topic-specific websites in a more organised and engaging way? Travel back to 1998 and Check out this article that introduces the concept of web rings. Back then, they were described as interconnected universes of websites, allowing you to navigate between them and discover related content. Say goodbye to dead links and hello to a more efficient and curated online exploration!

title: The Strange Story of the Teens Behind the Mirai Botnet
description: Their DDoS malware threatened the entire Internet
notes: A look into the fascinating world of the Mirai botnet. Read about the origins, capabilities, and impacts of this infamous botnet, which wreaked havoc on the internet by compromising vulnerable IoT devices.

title: From the valley to the alley - The History of the Web
author: Jay Hoffmann
description: The Flatiron building is one of the most instantly recognizable buildings in New York City. Built at the beginning of […]

title: Tori Amos Bootleg Webring
site: GERTRUDE PRESS STANDS IN SOLIDARITY WITH BLACK LIVES MATTER, AND COMMITS TO CONTINUE TO FEATURE THE STORIES, ART AND VOICES OF THE BLACK QUEER AND TRANS PEOPLE WHO HAVE ALWAYS BEEN ON THE FRONT LINES OF REVOLUTION.
description: Once I was at a party when the music changed, drawing me from a sunny festive patio to the loudspeakers indoors. I hadn’t listened to this particular album in fifteen years, but knew every one of...
notes: The Tori Amos bootleg webring was a community of fans who collected and shared unofficial live recordings of Tori Amos concerts.

title: The Number Ones: Britney Spears’ “3”
description: In The Number Ones, I’m reviewing every single #1 single in the history of the Billboard Hot 100, starting with the chart’s beginning, in 1958, and working my way up into the present. Book Bonus Beat: The Number Ones: Twenty Chart-Topping Hits That Reveal the History of Pop Music.
notes: Britney Spears has bangers for days but only three have made it to number one. What?!

title: The Age of PageRank is Over | Kagi Blog
author: Vladimir Prelovac
description: When Sergey Brin and Larry Page came up with the concept of PageRank in their seminal paper The Anatomy of a Large-Scale Hypertextual Web Search Engine ( http://infolab.stanford.edu/pub/papers/google.pdf ) (Sergey Brin and Lawrence Page, Stanford University, 1998) they profoundly changed the way we utilize the web.
notes: Great read on the state of search. I'm going to give Kagi a try!

title: MACHETES DIPPED IN RUM
author: M
description: The Oral History of Bone Thugs-n-Harmony
notes: This is a super long read that goes into huge detail about Bone Thugs-N-Harmony all the way up to 2015.

title: Why I'm Leaving Neocities
author: biko
description: ight imma head out

title: The State of Neocities
author: biko
description: and why it will not be mainstream

title: The State of Neocities
author: biko
description: and why it will not be mainstream

title: Nostalgiamining vs. Forging the Future
description: Let's stop with the Geocities ripoffs already, alright?
notes: Some harsh truths here!

title: Neocities and a Lack of Passion
description: We need interesting people, now more than ever.

title: Revisiting "Passion"
description: A look back at my most contentious piece, "Neocities and a Lack of Passion".

title: Why I'm Leaving Neocities
notes: Biko shares why they've left Neocities

title: The State of Neocities
notes: Biko looks at the state of Neocities

title: A one-person oral history of Geocities HTML Chat
description: Geocities HTML Chat has been forgotten by the world. It is possible I am the only one who remembers it. I only half remember it.

title: Why Is the Web So Monotonous? Google.
author: Sandy Maguire
description: Discover the fascinating concept of the Monotonous Web.
notes:: embark on a thrilling journey into the Monotonous Web!

title: How Websites Die
author: Wesley Aptekar-Cassels
notes: The author looks to understand how websites die after researching defunct blogging platforms.

title: melankorin
notes: Kori sits down to think about what it takes to build a personal website.

title: Every person on the planet should have their own website 💡   Amin Eftegarie
notes: Every person on the planet should have their own website, on their own domain name, and blog about whatever they want.

title: My Journey Away from the JAMstack
description: The name is all but dead, nerfed by the company who invented it. Here’s why Netlify was ahead of its time and where everything went wrong.
notes: Interesting take, for now Netlify still does what I need it to do without issue so I’ll be sticking around. At least for now.

title: Splitting the Web
description: Splitting the Web écrit par Ploum, Lionel Dricot, ingénieur, écrivain de science-fiction, développeur de logiciels libres.

title: Building an iPod for 2022
description: I modified an old iPod Video with more storage, a new casing, and more battery life. Also some fancy software :)

title: Which iPod has the best quality audio? - Macintosh How To
author: Wayne
description: This article discusses the reasons for the difference in quality of the sound output of the various models of Apple iPod.

title: The Gamification of Reading Is Changing How We Approach Books
description: Since its inception in 2007, Goodreads has been a place where people can come together and rate their favorite books, find new authors, and more. This writer juggles the greater implications of the site with our current reading culture.

title: The Expanding Dark Forest and Generative AI
description: Proving you're a human on a web flooded with generative AI content

title: Interview with Kagi | DKB
description: The internet is run by adtech right now, and all the biggest companies are thriving on that, and I think the sooner we get out of that, the better. It is certainly going to be hard, and I'm not against ads per-se, but I'm against ads everywhere, ads by default, ads making our lives crappier and more miserable.
notes: The Internet is run by adtech, and all the big companies thrive on it. The sooner we don't have to deal with adtech, the better. Ads everywhere are the default and makes our Internet crappy and miserable.

title: The Birth and Death of the Yesterweb Forum Reveal Two Important Truths
description: While the death of the Yesterweb forum is a loss for the small web movement, it is symptomatic of greater problems.

title: The ‘90s Internet: When 20 hours online triggered an email from my ISP’s president
description: 1998 plea for restraint reveals a lost world where the 'Net was an opt-in experience.
notes: Yes. There was a time where you could be online too much. The author recalls in 1998, a plea for restraint from their ISP reveals a lost world where the Net was an opt-in experience.

title: A look at search engines with their own indexes
author: Rohan Kumar
description: A cursory review of all the non-metasearch, indexing search engines I have been able to find.
notes: The author, Seirdy, takes a look at all of the non-meta search, indexing search engines that they’ve been able to find. Published in November 2022, it’s amazing the number that are already no longer available.

title: The end of the Googleverse
author: Ryan Broderick
description: The last 25 years of Google’s history can be boiled down to a battle against the Google bomb. Is the search engine finally losing to its hijackers?
notes: “They were encouraging people to write on the web,” said Baio. Bloggers like Lenssen, Baio, and Beale felt like everything Google was doing was in service of making the internet better. The tools it kept launching felt tied to a mission of collecting the world’s information and helping people add more content to the web.

title: ZeroNet and the Future of the Internet
description: A ZeroNet review that also asks, is ZeroNet the future of the Internet?
notes: Cheapskates again takes a dive into alternet Internet protocols... Until recently, the conventional wisdom was that the Internet is beyond the control of governments. how naive the conventional wisdom sometimes is.
